Super!  Thanks for the fix, and for the excellent write-up.

I am not sure there is a standard but I believe that the commonly accepted practice is to use logging.config (https://docs.python.org/2/library/logging.config.html). You can use either dictConfig, if you load from .yaml, .json; or fileConfig if you use .ini style config files. fileConfig is slowly phased out, some things you can do with dictConfig are not implemented (and not going to be implemented) in fileConfig.

Ideally this should be combined with hierarchical approach to logging. I.e. each module defines it's own logger via `logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)` and then do all logging operations using this module level logger instead of a root logger (`logger.info('Foo bar')`).

This guy has a fairly comprehensive example of best logging practices in Python - http://victorlin.me/posts/2012/08/26/good-logging-practice-in-python

Privately we use modified `settings.py` with alttered `configure_logging()` that loads config from logging.yaml.

I can file a PR if anyone else is interested

You don't need a full MySQL running locally if you want remote metadata store. All you need is development libs/headers. On linux based systems you can get them by doing
`sudo apt-get install libmysqlclient-dev -y` .  That's all you need to make `pip install airflow[mysql]` work.

If you use OS X for local development then the easiest way to get these libraries is via homebrew. Install homebrew then run `brew install mysql-connector-c` then `pip install airflow[mysql]`

May be it can be added to FAQ (instead of installation docs) as I suspect many folks run into this `mysql_config not found` issue when trying to setup remote MySQL based metadata store

It feels like this thread might have died. 

We have a use-case for running daily DB snapshots using Airflow. We are running DB backups/snapshotting in Airflow, so that we can coordinate a DB snapshot with pausing DAGs that depend on that DB while it is down. If the DB snapshot DAG is paused for 3 days and the unpaused, we don't want it to run the DB snapshot for the past 3 days.. We have a work-around by checking the logic in the BashOperator itself, but I am wondering if we can leverage the `only_run_latest` idea as well.
Added note to installation.rst and cleaned up README a little bit
travis failure has nothing to do with the build
Please rebase the branch so that I can merge it!

AFAIK, that's not the intended use-case of trigger_dag. The date it runs is the datetime it was triggered. If you want to pass specific parameters to it, you can via the `--conf` flag, which accepts JSON payloads, as mentioned on https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/airflow-lesson-1-triggerdagrunoperator-siddharth-anand?trk=pulse_spock-articles

If you simply want to run specific dates in the past for a DAG but don't want to actually run the DAG, create a DAG with a non-None or non-once schedule, disable it (so the scheduler won't run it automatically), and trigger backfills for particular dates. Essentially, the `clear` & `backfill` (together) mechanism is the one you may want to use when executing date-specific fills.
@mistercrunch can also weigh in
Beyond the nit, I don't believe this follows the intent of trigger_dag. if a date is to be passed, why not use backfill? Closing the PR as it is not the intended use of trigger_dag.

Sounds very reasonable. In general, it's a good practice to have your tasks explicitly fail, so that the state of the tasks is very clear. Is there a reason why you don't want an exception to bubble up in its glory?
yeah coveralls.io was choking this morning, I just restarted the build...

@r39132 is right, `trigger_dag` is intended for on-demand DAGs as opposed to on-schedule DAGs. 

I can see how this can be confusing as there's no way to alter the DagRuns' state or create new ones from the CLI, only in the UI at the moment.

You're assuming that the ETL is non incremental which might be right for your pipeline but certainly isn't right for all use case. If I'm doing incremental loads and currently loading the 15th of the month, having some external job succeed for the 16th doesn't help me with my data for the 15th. Yes the job for the 16th can move forward, but the one for the 15th should still wait for its dependency.
I can take this one on. I'm working pretty extensively with SubDags for some of our pipelines.
Closing for now. Reach out to us on gitter if you need more context and there is some use-case not covered by other CLI commands.

Hmn.. When does this policy get applied? Is a restart required across the cluster or is it automatically applied with the config file is reloaded? How does it get applied in a distributed deployment?

proof for SignedJwtAssertionCredentials: https://google-api-python-client.googlecode.com/hg/docs/epy/oauth2client.client-pysrc.html#SignedJwtAssertionCredentials.__init__

Policy gets applied on the scheduler when the dagbag is loaded, it is automatically picked up when the config file is modified. If by distributed deployment you mean not using local executors then it should still be run when the dagbag is loaded.

Not sure if those were questions or things you wanted to add to the PR comments, but they should be added either way.
+1 Pending the one nit on snake_case

Yes, since this policy policy is meant to mutate tasks, it actually applies when the `airflow run` subprocess gets executed by the executor, meaning that all tasks that start after the settings file is changed should be impacted. 

For the changes to be visible on the web server (most likely on the Task Details page), you'll need to refresh the DAG (rightmost button on the icon list in the DAGs view).

If you were to mutate something that affect the scheduler (the `queue` for instance), by default it fully refreshes the DagBag every 10 runs, though refreshing from the UI should do it here and affect the very next scheduling cycle.
The previous setup would allow to queue to empty out even when the DAG was paused. No new tasks would get queued, but the ones in the queue were allowed to drain...
It looks like transient errors, we've been having travis/coveralls issues lately
it's OK. thanks a lot!

Hmm - restarting scheduler and then webserver fixed it.  Our deploy is restarting the webserver anyway immediately after the new dags are copied.
I found the answer [here](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/quota-policy#queries). 128MB compressed. In our case we are retrieving 10+ million rows which accounts for around 2GB uncompressed csv.

LGTM

Oh yeah, I remember this one. That's a `flask_admin` bug. It's related to having a date field in a model's pk, and specific to sqlite since it doesn't auto-cast.

As far as Airflow goes, it seems somewhat low-pri since no-one should be using sqlite in production...
pymysql isn't supported, please use `mysqlclient`
Until we get more dynamic DagBags, `pkfill -f gunicorn`, you can also set the scheduler to reload the DAG definition every N runs.
Great thanks for the input I will give it a whirl on our next deploy
This might not work if the Qubole client is not picklable, right?
Sorry for n00b question, but Qubole client should be picklable, as its just a python object?

Usually, objects that encapsulate credentials tend to mark these fields as not picklable. It's the case for the boto client for AWS for instance. I do not know how the Qubole client works here so I am assuming you have tested it.
Thanks for the info Arthur, I'll test it out.

DagRun status is for the scheduler only, backfill is unaware of it and doesn't alter it.

I'm not sure why your `up_for_retry` tasks aren't getting picked up. Are you sure you waited for the whole duration of the `retry_interval`?
What's the trigger_rule on `join`? Seems like you could set it to `one_success`.

I'd put more emphasis on the idea of repeating patterns using subdags. Maybe the bullet I wrote about it should be a paragraph at the top. 

Oh and maybe a screenshot of the "zoom into subdag" button would help understanding how you get there, though it isn't necessary.

My current guess for the continued backfill is that past the 2014-08-07 end date is that once the DAG had its first DAG run at 2014-08-02, it used that at the start_date going forward, and disregarded my DAG's start_date that was defined in Python.

I expected the execution just to back fill those two days, and then pick up on the start_date defined in my Python file for further executions.
